src.porosity module¶

class src.porosity.Porosity(z_grid, layers, theta, soil, p_model)[source]¶

Bases: object

This class creates a porosity object. A porosity profile (field) is generated, as a function of the depth (z), along with the relevant field capacity and wilting point profiles (as functions of depth).

Naturally the porosity in the soil decreases with depth because the free empty pores are smaller in size, therefore allowing for less water to be kept at any given depth. However, depending on the type (or mixture) of soils this profile can vary.

f_interp¶
field_cap¶

Accessor of the underground layers.

Returns

Tuple with the (L0, L1, …)

src.richards_pde module¶

class src.richards_pde.RichardsPDE(m_data=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Richards’ PDE model equations. It represents the movement of water in un- saturated soils.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richards_equation

The PDE discretization code here mimics MATLAB’s “pdepe” function to solve 1-D parabolic and elliptic PDEs.

property arg_out¶

Gives access to the variable output arguments.

Returns

Dictionary with output values.

Boundary Conditions (top and bottom).

  • y_left – y(z_left, t)

  • z_right – location(s) 2

  • y_right – y(z_right, t)

  • args – additional arguments.

Returns

p_left, q_left, p_right, q_right

h_model¶
ic_fun(y0, *args)[source]¶

This function can model the initial conditions vector. In this case is a simple assignment, but it can handle mode complex initializations if required.

Parameters

  • y0 – initial conditions vector y(z,t=0) [dim_d].

  • args – to pass additional parameters if requested.

Returns

initial conditions vector.

nx¶
pde_fun(z, y, dydz, *args)[source]¶

Richards’ Equation (PDE - 1d).

Parameters

z – spatial discretization grid, i.e. the depth values at which

we want to return the solution of the PDE. [dim_d]

Parameters

  • y – is the state vector of the PDE, y(z,t=t0). [dim_d]

  • dydz – is the derivative of the PDE i.e. dydt(z,t). [dim_d].

  • args – additional input parameters of the PDE.

Returns

C (specific moisture capacity), sink, flux.

sim_flags¶
solve(t_span, y0, *args)[source]¶

This function numerically integrates a system of ordinary differential equations (self), within the time span “t”, given an initial value y0.

Parameters

  • t_span – time window to integrate the ode (t0, tf).

  • y0 – initial conditions array [dim_d].

  • args – additional model parameters.

Returns

dydt [dim_d].

src.simulation module¶

class src.simulation.Simulation(name=None, seed=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Main simulation class. The normal workflow is as follow:

1) Create a simulation object. You can also give a name that will be used when saving the data.

>> sim_01 = Simulation(“Sim_01”)

  1. Setup its parameters and water data (precipitation, etc.).

    >> sim_01.setupModel(params, water_data)

  2. Run the simulation (this step might take a while).

    >> sim_01.run()

  3. Finally save the results in a hdf5 (compressed) file.

    >> sim_01.saveResults()

initial_conditions()[source]¶

Creates an initial conditions vector, by running the PDE model forward in time for ‘burn-in’ number of iterations.

Returns

y0 state vector [dim_d].

mData¶
name¶
output¶
pde_model¶
rng¶
run()[source]¶

Runs the PDE model forward in time. All the output information is store in self.output dictionary where we can later save it to the disk for further analysis.

Returns

None

saveResults()[source]¶

Saves the simulation results to a file. All the data should be stored inside the self.output dictionary and be of type “numpy.ndarray”. For the moment the file is saved in the same directory as the main program.

Returns

None.

setupModel(params, data)[source]¶

This method is called BEFORE the run() and sets up all the variables for the simulation. It is also responsible for checking the validity of the input parameters before use.

Parameters

params – (dict) contains all the given parameters. If None, then it

will use the default parameters to initialize object. However this is not recommended since the user will have no control on the parameters.

Parameters

data – (pandas.DataFrame) that will contain the water data for the

simulation. These include, time-series of the dates, water table depths precipitation values, etc.

Returns

None.

Raises

  • ValueError – if some data are missing.

  • RuntimeError – TBD.

src.simulation.loadResults(filename=None)[source]¶

Loads the simulation data that have been stored in the hdf5 file using the object’s method saveResults().

Parameters

filename – (string) is the ‘.h5’ file that contains the data.

Returns

a dictionary with all the data.

src.tree_roots module¶

class src.tree_roots.TreeRoots(ln, dz, r_model, porous)[source]¶

Bases: object

This class models tree roots. It computes the roots density for a given depth and also returns roots efficiency, as described in refs. [1, 2].

To have more consistent results, the root depth in here is mapped to a predefined range [1 to 100].

1) Chun-Ta Lai and Gabriel Katul (2000): The dynamic role of root-water uptake in coupling potential to actual transpiration. Advances in Water Resources, Vol. 23, pages: 427-439.

2) D. B. G. Collins and R. L. Bras (2007): Plant rooting strategies in water-limited ecosystems. Water Resources Research, Vol. 43, W06407, doi:10.1029/2006WR005541, pages: 1-10.

dz¶
efficiency(theta_z, z_roots)[source]¶

This method computes the root efficiency as the product of two terms:

( i) alpha01 -> maximum efficiency, when the water is not limiting, (ii) alpha02 -> root shutdown.

The method is vectorized for faster execution, when the input matrix “theta” has multiple columns [dim_d x dim_m].

Parameters

  • theta_z – soil moisture values at depth(s) ‘z’. [dim_d x dim_m]

  • z_roots – depth values at which we want to return the root efficiency. [dim_d x 1]

Returns

  1. root efficiency (alpha01 * alpha02) [dim_d x dim_m]

  2. available water in the root zone [1 x 1]

Raises

RuntimeError – if the input dimensions do not match.

src.utilities module¶

src.utilities.find_wtd(y=None)[source]¶

This function identifies the location of the water table depth (wtd) and returns its index value. It starts the search from the bottom of the input vector and continues going upwards until the cell in question is not saturated. It assumes that the “wtd” exists right below the first non-saturated cell.

Parameters

y – bool vector with the saturated cells. (dim_d,).

Returns

the index at the first “True”, from the end of the vector.

src.utilities.logN_rnd(mx, vx, en)[source]¶

Log-Normal function. If X follows the log-normal distribution with parameters ‘mu’ and ‘sigma’: X ~ LogN(mu, sigma), then log(X) follows the normal distribution with mean ‘mu’ and standard deviation ‘sigma’: log(X) ~ N(mu, sigma).

Example (from python console):

>> x = logN_rnd(5.0, 1.0, np.random.randn(10000))

>> x_mean = np.mean(x)

>> … 4.992025079986667 (which is almost 5.0)

Parameters

  • mx – desired mean (of the Normal distribution).

  • vx – desired variance (of the Normal distribution).

  • en – random variable N(0, 1)

Returns

a random variable drawn from LogNormal(mu, sigma)
